Title: How Nicole Kidman & Keith Urban Are Striving to Keep Divorce Respectful: Parenting Plan Revealed
Description:
Hollywood superstar Nicole Kidman and former “American Idol” judge Keith Urban are keeping their family at the forefront as they navigate their divorce. Court documents obtained by People reveal that the couple has agreed to a parenting plan centered on their daughters, Sunday Rose, 17, and Faith Margaret, 14. 

People report that the plan prohibits either parent from speaking negatively about the other in the children's presence. It emphasizes the importance of encouraging the girls to feel loved and supported in both homes.

As part of the agreement, Kidman and Urban will also attend a parenting seminar within 60 days of the filing, underscoring their shared commitment to raising their daughters with respect and stability.

As per People, the court documents also confirm that Kidman will serve as the primary residential parent of the couple's teenage daughters. She will have 306 days with Sunday Rose and Faith Margaret, while Urban will have 59. The arrangement gives Kidman more than five times the number of parenting days her estranged husband has. 

Neither parent will pay monthly child support, as Urban has already covered his obligations through a separate agreement.

Alongside her two younger daughters, Kidman is also the mother of Bella, 32, and Connor, 30, whom she shares with her ex-husband, Tom Cruise. The Oscar winner officially filed for divorce from Urban in Nashville on Sept. 30, the day after news of their separation became public.

A post shared by Nicole Kidman (@nicolekidman)

An insider told People that Kidman “didn't want this” and had been “fighting to save the marriage.” A source close to Urban said the country star has “been going through some stuff” and making “questionable choices” in recent months.

A post shared by Nicole Kidman (@nicolekidman)

Kidman and Urban's love story began in 2005 when they first met at a gala. A year later, they tied the knot in a candlelit ceremony in Sydney, where Kidman's children Bella and Connor took part in the wedding. By 2007, the couple had settled into life in Nashville, where they raised their two daughters.

Despite the challenges, Kidman has continued to cherish her bond with her teenage girls. In a May interview with Allure, she shared: “Yeah, I'm very close to both my girls. I sit on their beds and discuss the most intimate things; I get to be their guide.”

She added, “If they want to tell me to be quiet, they can. I'm able to apologize to them. I'm able to stand up to them. I very much like the relationship we have. It's nice to be able to say that.”

Sources previously told People that Kidman spent the summer inseparable from her daughters while Urban toured. She focused on preparing them for the new school year, enjoying time together at home in Nashville.

Title: Kate Gosselin Shares Painful Health Update After Major Surgery
Description:
Kate Gosselin is offering fans a candid look at her health journey following a recent medical procedure she described as one of the most painful experiences of her life.

The former “Jon & Kate Plus 8” star, 50, took to TikTok on Tuesday, September 30, to reveal that she recently underwent surgery and is currently recovering.

While she did not share specifics about the procedure itself, Gosselin explained just how challenging the process has been.

“I had surgery this morning and have five pain meds on board (top 3 most painful surgery),” the reality TV star began.

“I am not in a position to go into the details now but only bc I can't focus. I did well,” Gosselin added.

She added that when she is feeling better, she will give fans more details on what happened.

Alongside the message, she shared an image of herself post-surgery, while she is recovering.

Her honesty struck a chord with fans, who quickly filled the comments with supportive words and prayers.

“Prayers for a quick recovery Kate,” one user wrote.

“Get well soon Kate. You are strong and willing xo,” another added.

Many thanked her for being so open, noting that her vulnerability encourages others going through similar medical struggles.

“Sending love and strength your way. Thank you for being real about how hard this is,” one follower shared.

Prior to the update, Gosselin shared an image of herself on Monday, September 29, from a hospital bed with IVs in her arms, as she asked fans for prayers.

“Emergencies don't care about schedules!” she began. “Please DON'T worry about me! Please pray instead! Don't worry, story time to follow when I'm able! Love you guys! I'll be back as soon as I can!”

Gosselin, who became a household name on TLC when the network documented her life raising twins and sextuplets, has stepped back from the spotlight in recent years.

Now, her social media posts serve as a window into her life beyond television, and her latest update reminded fans of her resilience.

Though she didn't disclose a timeline for her recovery, Gosselin reassured her followers that she is committed to getting better day by day.

The update marks one of Gosselin's most personal shares in recent months.

While she has kept a lower profile since her reality TV days, she continues to connect with her fan base by speaking honestly about the highs and lows she faces.

Most recently, she shared that she is dating again and has been in a relationship for roughly a year. The mystery man was later revealed to be Steve Neild, her longtime former bodyguard.

Title: Kim Kardashian Reflects on Robert Kardashian Sr.'s Last Wish
Description:
Kim Kardashian remembered her father, Robert Kardashian Sr., with a moving Instagram tribute on the 22nd anniversary of his death. She shared family photos with her siblings and reposted a touching video on Instagram about missing her dad. Her caption read, “Thank you for always protecting the family from heaven…” showing fans the lasting impact of his guidance.

“My dad knew everything as dads do,” she said in the video. “And I think that's what I miss the most. I could call him with a question on politics, law, on my car, on a piece of wood, on a job. He always knew the answer. And that's what is missing from me now. Having that shelter. Knowing that when you look up, he's covering you. There was a layer above me, and now it's gone. He was my shelter.”

Robert Kardashian Sr. was not only a famous attorney but also a devoted father. During a very unforgettable episode of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians,” Bruce Jenner (now Caitlyn Jenner) recalled a private moment from Robert's final days. On his deathbed, Robert asked Bruce to look after his four children—Kourtney, Kim, Khloé, and Rob Jr.—both emotionally and financially.

That request showed his deep love and foresight. Even as his health declined, he focused on protecting his children's future. He passed away in 2003 from esophageal cancer at the age of 59. Kim was just 22 at the time, making the loss even more profound.

“I've known you just as long as you've been gone,” she wrote in her Instagram caption. “I hope you're so proud of all of us.”

Robert Sr. earned recognition for his role defending O.J. Simpson in the trial of the century. His legal skills made headlines, but his dedication to his family defined his true legacy. Today, Kim continues that spirit of advocacy. Her efforts in criminal justice reform echo her father's values and passion for fairness.

The link between father and daughter is clear. Robert Sr. fought for his clients. Kim now fights for those unfairly sentenced. Both used their platforms to champion justice, showing the family's shared dedication to causes larger than themselves.

Robert Sr. also passed down a strong sense of heritage. Proud of his Armenian background, he made sure his children valued their culture. The Kardashian sisters have honored this on their shows, traveling to Armenia and speaking publicly about their roots.

His financial stability and values gave his children a strong foundation. That base allowed them to become business leaders and global influencers. Kim's SKIMS, Khloé's Good American, and Kourtney's Poosh all reflect the discipline he instilled. Rob Jr. also honors him by carrying his name into a new generation.

Kim's tribute was more than a memory. It was a reminder of a father whose deathbed promise still shapes one of the most powerful families in entertainment. Robert Kardashian Sr. gave his children more than wealth—he gave them strength, identity, and purpose.

Title: Fans Flood Christina Haack With Support as She Opens Up About Her ‘Mistakes'
Description:
Longtime HGTV star Christina Haack is feeling the love — finally. Gracing the latest cover of People magazine — released on October 1, 2025 — the designer and mom of three is opening up about learning from her “mistakes,” especially in love. 

Since rising to fame on “Flip or Flop” with her first husband, Tarek El Moussa, Haack, 42, has often been mocked on social media for her headline-grabbing love life. She and El Moussa finalized their highly publicized divorce in January 2018, and she's since been married and divorced twice more — to fellow TV personality Ant Anstead and former police officer Josh Hall. 

“I'm grateful for my mistakes,” Haack says on People magazine's cover, which the outlet shared via social media. Her statements about learning and growing through all the unexpected twists have prompted many fans to shower her with praise and thanks on the posts. 

A post shared by People Magazine (@people)

Haack's third divorce, from Hall, was finalized in August, 13 months after the couple broke up while filming the first season of HGTV's “The Flip Off.” The renovation competition, which was meant to pit Hall and Haack against El Moussa and his second wife, Heather Rae El Moussa. 

After highlighting the breakup in the first episode, the unlikely trio of Haack and the El Moussas carried on without Hall. The show was such a hit in early 2025 that they've just begun filming a second season. 

Haack has been dating business exec Christopher Larocca since late 2024, frequently posting social media pics from their travels and dinners out. 

“I don't look at it as starting over, and especially for the fourth time,” Haack told People. “That just makes me want to cringe. It does feel like a fresh start in that for once I'm actually in control of my destiny, and that feels really good.”

Haack has a full plate, between the show, her design work, and her just-launched champagne, plus navigating a blossoming relationship while parenting her three kids — 14-year-old Taylor and 10-year-old Brayden, whom she shares with El Moussa, and six-year-old Hudson, whom she shares with Antstead. 

“I'm not going to say I have it all together,” she admitted to People. “I'm still learning. I'm still a work in progress. And I'm grateful for my mistakes.”

Fans and friends have rallied around Haack with the publication of her People interview, with many commenting on social media that they've been inspired by her vulnerability and resilience. 

Hundreds liked one person's thoughtful comment, which said, “People act like they don't make mistakes and wanna judge. We all make mistakes, some just hides them in their closets or burry them. Best of luck!”

“You are an inspiration,” another wrote. “It is not how many times we fall down, but how we get back up and grow and learn.💜💜”

Someone else offered, “You seem happy and that's all that matters! Wishing you all the best 💞🙏🏽”

Another wrote, “Shine On !!! You owe nothing to people that don't know you, yet judge you! I think you are amazing! It's your life enjoy it! I can't wait to try your 🥂🍾”

Even Tarek weighed in, drawing hundreds of likes for joking, “I will never stop saying it. I'm still number one!!! if you ain't first you're last”

Title: Fans Thrilled About Scott Wolf's Return to TV After Tough Summer: ‘Grateful'
Description:
Fans of “Party of Five” alum and Hallmark fan favorite Scott Wolf are cheering on the actor and dad of three over news that he will soon return to FOX's “Doc” and even direct an episode of the hit show. 

The positive news, first reported by Variety on September 30, 2025, is a breath of fresh air for Wolf's fans after months of tough headlines regarding his surprise split from his wife of 21 years, Kelley Wolf, and her personal struggles since their June 10 announcement. 

A post shared by Conscious Hollywood (@conscioushollywoodpr)

Scott starred as Dr. Richard Miller in all 10 episodes of the first season of “Doc,” which premiered in January with record-breaking ratings. But after his character, the Chief of Internal Medicine at Westside Hospital, was fired in the season finale, he has not appeared in the first episodes of season two. Felicity Huffman has joined the cast, playing the new Chief of Internal Medicine. 

But Scott, who also broke ratings records with Lacey Chabert in 2023's “A Merry Scottish Christmas,” will  return to the series “in a multi-episode guest arc” later in the 22-episode season, per Variety, and will direct an episode to air in early 2026.

In a statement, co-executive producers Barbie Kligman and Hank Steinberg said, “We always knew when Richard got fired that would never be the last of him. But no one expected him to come back to Westside like this — least of all Amy.”

Scott made a rare but brief appearance on social media in light of the news, sharing Fox's post about his return in his Instagram Stories on September 30, writing “Grateful.” 

A post shared by Drama Club FOX (@dramaclubfox)

When Fox tagged Scott in a post that appeared in his feed, fans flooded the actor with comments to express their relief and joy, including one who wrote, “Yayyyy!!! So well deserved! I cannot wait to see what his character does!”

Someone else exclaimed, “🙌 Omg so happy!!! Well deserved! 🙏🙏🙏”

Scott's co-star Darrin Baker, who plays the CEO of Westside, commented, “Just fantastic! See ya in a few …Love this!!”

Many fans breathed a sigh of relief over the news of Scott's return, following nearly four months of dealing with grave challenges stemming from his breakup. One fan wrote on his Instagram update, “So good to hear. Hope your personal life has calmed down and the kids are ok. All the best to u”

Days after his split from Kelley, Scott was awarded sole custody of their three kids and has also been granted restraining orders and protective orders since. Kelley has been placed under two involuntary holds and faces four misdemeanor charges connected to sharing personal information about Scott and their children on social media. 

On September 30, the same day Scott's return to “Doc” was announced, TMZ reported that Kelley didn't show up for a scheduled court hearing in Summit County, Utah, where the family has lived for years. 

According to the outlet, the judge said that Kelley was “unable to attend” her hearing regarding multiple misdemeanor charges because she'd checked into a mental health facility. Prosecutor Wendy Crossland added that she “believes” Kelley is in treatment, per People, and said, “I have not otherwise had any other contact with Miss Wolf.”

If Kelley is seeking help, it would be the second time in a month she's checked into a treatment facility. She previously checked into a center in early September, People reported, but only stayed for two days. 

According to the outlet, the Scotts' next divorce hearing is set for October 23, and Kelley has also “received a summons to appear in court on November 7 regarding her latest arrest.”

Title: Hallmark Channel Stars Selling the Clothes Off Their Backs For Charity (at AMAZING Prices!)
Description:
Items from popular movie wardrobes occasionally go up for sale, purchased by avid collectors or to raise money for charity. Superman's cape was scooped up for $193,000. Darth Vader's helmet sold for $898,000. But Andrew Walker's hiking vest from Hallmark Channel's new “Adventures in Love and Birding?” That could be yours for just $20. 

On October 1, 2025, Hallmark's public relations team revealed that the network is teaming up with Luxanthropy to sell the wardrobes from four movies this year, starting with “Adventures in Love and Birding,” which premiered on September 27 starring Walker and Rachel Boston. 

Best of all, proceeds from every wardrobe item sold will go to Reach Out Worldwide (ROWW), the nonprofit organization for which fellow Hallmark actor John Brotherton has been a longtime ambassador. 

The fundraiser comes on the heels of a Romance University raffle that featured Hallmark movie wardrobe items from stars Benjamin Ayres and Tyler Hynes, which raised a whopping $20,000 for cancer charities in September.

Over 50 wardrobe pieces from Hallmark Channel's “Adventures in Love and Birding” are available while supplies last, and each item is surprisingly inexpensive, from Walker's UNIGLO olive suit for just $65 to Boston's tan hooded parka for $29. 

“GIVING BACK to our communities on a local and national level is an important part of our work at @hallmarkchannel,” Hallmark's PR team wrote on Instagram. “To augment our sustainability efforts and raise funds for worthy causes, we piloted a program with LuxAnthropy to sell clothing and apparel from movies and series where all proceeds go to charity.”

Walker shared the post in his Instagram Stories and wrote, “Shooting movies is fulfilling but when you're able to give back while doing it, that's the 🍒 on top.”

A post shared by Reach Out WorldWide (@reachoutww)

Proceeds will go to ROWW, founded by the late actor Paul Walker. Brotherton, who appeared in “Fast and Furious 7,” has been involved with the foundation for more than a dozen years. The organization provides on-the-ground assistance to families impacted by natural disasters, and has been instrumental in helping the thousands of Los Angeles residents impacted by wildfires that swept through the city in January. 

Brotherton and his wife Alison have been on the frontlines of ROWW's work in L.A. since the fires began blazing across entire communities, including the hardest-hit Altadena neighborhood and Pacific Palisades. 

“For anyone who knows what that's like (to lose your home), it's why we're trying to provide a moment to take a breath,” he told EntertainmentNow in early 2025. “Have your needs met, have a conversation, come back if we can fulfill more as your needs unfold — anything from a bed to toothpaste.” 

A post shared by Romance University (@romance__university)

In another creative use of Hallmark wardrobe items, Ayres — who started the Romance University online community and fundraising initiative in early 2023 — put his light-up sweater from “The Santa Class” up for grabs and recruited Hynes to contribute one of his suits from a recent movie. 

Hallmark fans joined the raffle for $10 a ticket in September and managed to raise an incredible $20,000, which was divided up for two cancer charities — Gilda's Club of Toronto and Childhood Cancer Canada. 

In a thank you to everyone who contributed, Ayres wrote, ” Together, we're proving that love, connection, and generosity can make a real difference. 💫 Thank you for showing up and giving back, this community continues to inspire. 💛”

Title: Mark Kerr Didn't Want the Darkest Parts of His Life Sanitized for ‘The Smashing Machine'
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Writer/director Benny Safdie‘s “The Smashing Machine” is a true story that exalts its subject — mixed martial arts pioneer Mark Kerr (played by Dwayne Johnson) — without shying away from the dark parts of his life. The film honors Kerr's achievements in the ring while also presenting his drug addiction, depression, and dysfunctional relationship with Dawn Staples (Emily Blunt) in a series of uncomfortably raw scenes where Safdie turns the audience into uninvited voyeurs to Kerr's worst moments.

“It's a story about the human condition, good, bad, and indifferent,” Kerr told IndieWire of the film. “Dwayne, Emily, and Benny all embrace those complexities and wanted to bring them all out.” Kerr's story had been told before in a 2002 documentary of the same name, but he felt mild trepidation about a warts-and-all biopic in the age of social media. “We're in a totally different era now with everybody's ability to put their opinion out there.”

 








Related Stories ‘Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair' to Receive Nationwide Release — We Called It Tarantino's Best Movie Keep Calm and ‘Rocky Horror' on: The 50-Year-Old Cult-Film Comfort Watch Just Took Over Los Angeles 

Kerr's concerns were quickly assuaged by conversations with Johnson and Safdie, who assured him that they would depict his journey with honesty and empathy. “It was this heartfelt thing,” Kerr said of his first long conversation with Johnson when the movie started to move forward. “He said, ‘I'm ready to do something completely different, and this is the vehicle I'm going to do it in.”

 










Safdie, meanwhile, earned Kerr's trust by opening up about his own struggles. “I said, ‘I'm gonna tell you my life story, because you're trusting me with yours,'” Safdie told IndieWire. “And I told him everything. All the dark stuff, all the bad things that hurt me, all the wounds that are still there. I just let him know everything, and I trusted him.”

Safdie was clear, however, that he wasn't going to make any compromises when it came to showing Kerr at his lowest. “ I said, ‘I'm not gonna pull any punches,' for lack of a better analogy,” Safdie said, “but I really do feel that the world can benefit from experiencing your life. As we spoke, I realized that there were a lot of shared things that we had experienced, and I understood why, when I had watched him in the documentary, I felt like I got him.”

For Johnson and Blunt, Kerr's cooperation and input were essential steps toward crafting their performances. “  It was essential for Dwayne and I to have access to Mark and Dawn, because then all of the nuance you learn about them makes its way in,” Blunt told IndieWire. “I would be scared if someone wanted to make a movie about the most tumultuous times of my life, but Mark is such an open book.  He really is tender at his core and self-reflective in a way that is pretty astonishing. He was extremely ready to be vulnerable and tell you everything.”

 










When Johnson talked with Kerr while preparing for the role, the discussions were less about the technical aspects of the scenes in the ring than about Kerr's emotional state. “The conversations I had with Mark were about loss,” Johnson told IndieWire. “We all go through wins and losses in life, but Mark's loss was in front of 40,000 people, and then he spiraled. He overdosed twice and was knocking on death's door.”

Kerr told Johnson that when he lost that first big fight, his body couldn't move, but he refused to stop the fight. “He said, ‘As much as I was numb, as much as I couldn't move, there were 40,000 people there, and they came to see me,'” Johnson said. “‘I didn't want to let them down, so I wasn't going to quit.' Which said so much to me as I prepared for the role — that this man at his lowest didn't want to quit.”

As Johnson got to know Kerr, he realized that his opioid addiction was less about physical pain than shame, a topic Safdie wanted to lean into in his script. “There's a lot of shame in addiction, and there's a lot of shame in admitting and recovering from it,” Safdie said. “I didn't want to sanitize it because Mark doesn't sanitize it when he talks about his life. He's really able to own his mistakes.”

At one point, Kerr told Safdie the phrase, “Don't work my program,” which is something he said to his wife when he felt she was getting in the way of his progress. “I was like, bam, that goes right in the movie,” Safdie said. “Because that says everything about how hard it is if you're trying to get better and somebody's telling you what to do. So we would have these conversations about life and things we were going through because I needed to understand him, and they would find their way into the movie.”

 










For Kerr, seeing his story unfold on screen was cathartic not in spite of but because of the actors' willingness to present the characters at their most emotionally extreme. “It allowed me to see how hard I was on Dawn, and really admit that to myself,” Kerr said. “Fighting is incredibly selfish; it doesn't leave a lot of space for other people when it comes to emotion and intimacy. Breaking it down to its essence, Dawn was just a little girl who wanted to be loved, and I was just a boy that couldn't figure out how to love her.”

Watching the movie, Kerr was finally able to make peace with his own guilt. “ It really allowed me to see things in a way that I hadn't before,” he said. “It allowed me to get rid of those last little pieces of those things I was holding onto. A lot of that is realizing I'm a different person now, and Dawn's a different person. We have a beautiful 20-year-old son, and that's the focus of everything now, to be the best parents we can to him. When the movie showed at Venice, I couldn't believe how emotionally impactful it was. It was like therapy with a thousand people in the room. It was a beautiful experience.”

Kerr felt that watching the movie left him less vulnerable than that same experience did for Johnson.

“Everybody perceives him in a certain way,” Kerr said. “He does these huge blockbuster movies, and he has it down to a science; he's brilliant at it. It was riskier for him to do this than it was for me to expose all the dirty little things that were going on at the time, because no one has ever seen him like this. You see him in a completely different way than you've ever seen him on screen before.”

 










One of the movie's most powerful moments comes at the end, when, after two hours of watching Johnson's devastating performance, the audience sees the real Mark Kerr shopping in a grocery store. It's a brilliant way for Safdie to remind everyone that this is a true story about a man he doesn't want anyone to forget. “Mark said something really sad to me at one point,” Safdie said. “He said he felt like he had been discarded and forgotten. And I didn't want that for him.”

To that end, Safdie called Kerr and told him to come to the set in New Mexico, where he would be number one on the call sheet. “I'm like, ‘I don't know what that means,'” Kerr said. Safdie decided to shoot the film with an IMAX camera in an effort to make a point about the importance of Kerr's life. “We were shooting far away, on an 800-millimeter lens, a 1400-millimeter lens,” Safdie said. “It might be the first handheld IMAX zoom shot ever. But I'm not doing it where you think it would be.”

That's because Safdie wanted to give Kerr's everyday life a sense of epic grandeur. “I wanted to use this technology and this resolution to highlight the man in the real world, because that's as exciting and operatic as anything in the movie,” Safdie said. “That guy lived everything you just saw. His name is Mark Kerr, and I want people to know who he is.”

 










A24 opens “The Smashing Machine” in theaters on Friday, October 3.

Title: The Best Anime to Watch in Fall 2025
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

2025 has been a very strong year for anime all around, with shows both new and old showcasing the versatility and malleability of the medium. There's been a dark teen horror show that doubles as a metaphor for growing up gay, a sequel series to a legendarily weird “Powerpuff Girls” pastiche, and even an adaptation of “Anne of Green Gables” for our troubles. After a particularly packed summer filled with unique new shows, the industry seems to be slowing down slightly as it heads into the fall season. But as always, there's some gems if you know to look for them.

This October, the big projects (at least in the U.S.) people are paying the most attention to are less what's coming to streaming than what's coming to theaters. The main story right now is, obviously, the massive success of the new “Demon Slayer” film, which has already broken records as the highest-grossing anime movie of all time. Later this month, there will also be the “Chainsaw Man” film coming to theaters, serving as a sequel to the highly popular action horror series. 

On TV, most attention will be on the premiere of “My Hero Academia,” a highly popular show that — after nine years and eight seasons — is finally coming to a close with its last several episodes. Other returning shows include “Spy X Family,” a family comedy wrapped in an espionage plot, and “To Your Eternity,” a fantasy series with a thought-provoking look at the concept of immortality. 

There are fewer immediately buzzy original shows than usual this fall, but there's still some standouts. Those looking for a silly action show can get a kick out of “Sanda,” a series about the descendent of Santa Claus (yes, really). There's a queer romantic horror “The Monster Wants to Eat Me,” spinoffs of popular franchises “Gintama” and “Digimon,” and comedies like “May I Ask For One Final Thing?” and “Let's Play.” If you want a sure thing that we can guarantee is good: Netflix has been airing the sweet romance series “The Fragrant Flower Blooms with Dignity” for over a month now, and it's a lovely show well worth checking out.

Read on for our selections for the most promising anime TV series of the fall. Shows are listed in order of U.S. premiere date. 

Ludicrous title aside, “The Flagrant Flower Blooms with Dignity” is a remarkably grounded and sweet romance that finds real emotional depth and chemistry within its conventional story of unlikely love. Based on a manga by Saka Mikami, the series is set at two high schools located right next to each other: Chidori Public High School, a public school for delinquent boys, and Kikyo Private Academy Girls' High School, an exclusive institution for high class girls. Main characters Rintaro and Kaoruko attend the schools, and when the sweet Kaoruko recognizes Rintaro's hidden kindness, they develop a friendship that blooms into romance. The adaptation does the manga's writing justice, with beautiful animation and skilled voice acting that makes it an easy love story to sink into.

Currently streaming on Netflix. 

Just the third series from maker Studio Lings, “This Monster Wants to Eat Me” is based on a manga with a particularly twisted take on gay romance that has a whiff of “Yellowjackets” in it. The main character Hinako is a young woman who wishes to die, and meets a mermaid named Shiori who thirsts for her flesh and blood. Shiori begins shadowing the teen around, waiting for her to ripen into the “perfect meal,” and in the process, a very unusual romance blooms between the two.

Premieres October 2 on Crunchyroll. 

The rare romance anime to focus on adults with careers rather than teenagers, “Let's Play” is adapted from an extremely popular Webtoon comic published from 2016 to 2022, and was notably created by American author Leeanne M. Krecic. The main character, Sam Young, is a software developer in Los Angeles who has toiled for years working on her video game passion project and has never had time for a relationship. After her game gets published, she begins to dip her toes into the world of romance, developing feelings for an old friend, a manager at her software company, and a Youtuber who criticized her game and coincidentally moves next door to her. It's a likable, relatable tale about figuring life out in your 20s, and it's intriguing to watch it get translated into anime.  

Premieres October 2 on Crunchyroll. 

The loosely defined “villainess” genre in anime and manga essentially acts as a perspective switch for the romance genre, showing the love triangles from the perspective of the would-be doe-eyed heroines' way more interesting rival. A lot of these shows set this up by having the character reincarnated as a villainess in a video game or an anime, but “May I Ask For One Final Thing?” pivots by setting this story in a more fleshed-out fantasy world. The main character Scarlet, is a daughter of a Duke who gets dumped by her Prince fiancé in humiliating fashion at a ball, after he accuses her of being a bully. He's not right about that, but she proves even worse, as she unveils her hidden murderous side and goes on a bloody revenge tour against him and his loved ones.

Premieres October 3 on Crunchyroll. 

From Paru Itagaki, the manga artist behind the acclaimed “Beastars,” “Sanda” has a premise that seems like a joke. In a near future Japan struggling with a declining birth rate, a middle-school student discovers he's the descendant of Santa Claus, and has all the powers of Jolly Saint Nick. Using his powers, he fights crime and attempts to restore hope and save Christmas in the country. The manga takes this (mostly) seriously, and offers up some of the most notable violent Santa action in recent memory. The big selling point of the adaptation is that it comes from Science Saru, the makers behind great shows like “Dan Da Dan” and “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,” and known for a signature loose, demented animation style that should fit the material like a Santa hat. 

Premieres October 4 on Amazon Prime Video

Although it's culturally best known as “not-Pokémon,” “Digimon” animated spinoffs have always sneakily been way more interesting than its much more culturally dominant rival, with strong character writing and surprisingly ambitious narratives that make them hold up as far as kids' anime goes. Not much is known about the plot of the latest series “Beatbreak,” but it features a nifty animation style and a trailer that promises a relatively serious tone, and that's enough to pique some interest. 

Premieres on Crunchyroll and Hulu on October 4. 

One of the most remarkable and unique fantasy anime in recent memory, “To Your Eternity” follows the long, long life of Fushi, an immortal being who came down to the world as a clear white orb. Able to take the form of anything it touches, including living beings after their death, Fushi first takes on the form of a dying wolf, and then that of the young boy who owns the wolf after his own tragic passing. Venturing through the world in the boy's form, Fushi slowly develops consciousness and independent thought, meets and loses many people he comes to love, and becomes more disenchanted with his life as an immortal being. A heartbreaking show that thoughtfully looks at grief, loss, and the passage of time, Season 3 jumps forward in Fushi's lifetime to a period in the fantasy world's history that's roughly on par with modern technology.

Premieres October 4 on Crunchyroll

One of the more popular anime of the 2020s, “Spy x Family” is a heartwarming romantic comedy wrapped up in the plot of an espionage thriller. Loid Forger is a spy from Westalis (a fictional West Germany, basically) who takes on a fake name to live in the neighboring country of Ostania (East Germany) and carry out his subterfuge. As part of his cover, he also convinces city hall clerk Yor to enter a sham marriage with him, and adopts young orphan Anya, while keeping his dual identity secret. But his makeshift family has secrets of their own: Yor is actually a professional assassin, while Anya was a test subject of experiments that gave her telepathic abilities. Spy action thus takes a backseat to slowburn romance and heartwarming family comedy as each member of the family struggles to hide their secrets, all while Yor and Loid slowly fall in love for real and come to appreciate Anya as a true daughter.    

Premieres October 4 on Crunchyroll. 

If you want to get into “My Hero Academia” now that the series is finally coming to a close, you have a lot of catch-up to do: The massively popular series about teenagers training to become superheroes has 159 episodes already, on top of four theatrical film spinoffs. But that's a task worth taking on, because the show has been one of the best action series of the last several years, blending together superhero tropes with heartfelt and relatable coming-of-age drama into an accessible and exhilarating formula. And the eighth and final season is guaranteed to be the most talked and buzzed about series this fall.

Premieres October 4 on Crunchyroll. 

Known in Japan by the charmingly convoluted name of “3-nen Z-gumi Ginpachi-sensei,” “Mr. Ginpachi's Zany Class” is a spinoff of the beloved comedy series “Gintama,” known for parodying and lampooning other anime and for its quirky, silly sense of humor. Set in a loose alternate history of Edo-period Japan, where the country was conquered by an alien race named the Amanto, it follows a lazy samurai named Gintoki Sakata who does odd jobs around the country to pay for rent. It's not the type of series that has particularly tight continuity, but you need no context to go into the spinoff “Mr. Ginpachi's Zany Class,” which asks the question: What if Gintoki was a teacher, and the rest of the cast of the original show was his students? The answer is, mostly, a series with a sense of humor and tone that is pretty much identical to “Gintama” already.

Premieres October 6 on Crunchyroll.

Title: Joachim Trier Tells Us He'd Never ‘Begged an Actor' to Work with Him Before — Until ‘Mr. Cinema' Stellan Skarsgård
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Sitting down with a director for the first time is one of my favorite things. It's a get-to-know-you session, even if it's just a half hour in the lobby of New York's Ritz-Carlton Hotel. I'm meeting Norway's Joachim Trier, the fast-talking Cannes Grand Prix winner of “Sentimental Value” (Neon, November 7), who co-wrote his sixth feature with his long-time collaborator Eskil Vogt, his fellow “Worst Person in the World” Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominee. The Academy also nominated that film for Best International Feature Film. And given its warm reception so far from critics and audiences, Norwegian Oscar entry “Sentimental Value” is likely to nab even more nominations this Oscar season.
 








Related Stories Mark Kerr Didn't Want the Darkest Parts of His Life Sanitized for ‘The Smashing Machine' ‘Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair' to Receive Nationwide Release — We Called It Tarantino's Best Movie 

Trier took me on a wild ride through his film family and filmmaking philosophy and process, which includes “jazz takes.” (More on that later.) With “Sentimental Value,” two decades of digging into the human and artistic psyche has yielded his most universal film, which tracks generational trauma within a show business family. After winning the Grand Prix at Cannes and turning away eager passholders in Telluride, “Sentimental Value” has gone on to wow theater audiences in France and Norway, and this week, the New York Film Festival. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






That's partly because Trier successfully wooed Norway's Renate Reinsve to return to his ensemble to play Nora Borg, a revered stage actress, as well as Swedish star Stellan Skarsgård, who plays her father, Gustav, a once-successful auteur now in decline who tries to persuade his daughter to make a movie with him. He desperately wants to mend broken bridges, but she isn't having it, and he moves on to an American star (Elle Fanning), even though she's a bad fit for the role.

Both Reinsve and Skarsgård give towering performances that will not be denied at Oscar time (for Best Actress and Supporting Actor, respectively), given that Neon, which bought the film at Cannes 2024 before production, is adept at playing the awards game.

The following interview has been edited and condensed for clarity and length. 

Anne Thompson: Your film is hitting universal chords. How many of us have been traumatized by our parents?

Joachim Trier: It's the nature of human beings almost.

This film is informed by your own culturally rich background. 

I come from a film family. My grandfather, Erik Løchen, a film director, was in Cannes in 1960. And he created art. I knew him as a child. He passed away when I was nine. He was in the resistance during the Second World War and was captured and spent time in a work camp and barely survived. He was affected by it his whole life, but started playing jazz and making movies. “The Hunt,” his first film, he called the “jazz movie.” And the French called it “Nouvelle Vague.” I believe that art can have a saving power. It's not something done just for purpose. It's something you do because you don't know how not to. I see it in my children as well. They dance and sing, and they're very small: “So this is what humans do, okay?”

 










But also humans become obsessed and chase achievement and ignore children. 

I have two daughters, one and a half and four and a half years old. I had children late. I've pondered upon how obsessed I am by making movies, and would I be able to create a home? I was ready, in a way, and I'm making a film about that as well. I believe in that balance and possibility. That came out of that climate of being in middle age, still having parents, having small children. You have a feeling that things move fast, and maybe not wanting to be Stellan's character, who is complicated and egocentric.

When he pitches Nora to star in his movie, it doesn't land well. 

It's his only way of trying to connect. If you look at it from her point of view, she's grieving her mother, and she needs a father, and he's offering her a job. But if you look closely, it's a clumsy man without a language and emotionality that's trying desperately to connect with the daughter that he loves. So that's the sadness of it. I'm trying to straddle or balance these two energies of different perspectives. 

Throughout the film, Skarsgård is operating on many levels, saying one thing while his face says something else. 
 










I wrote this film for two actors. It's Renate Reinsve and Skarsgard. I never worked with him before. I didn't even know him. I contacted him during the writing process and flew to Sweden. And I've never begged an actor before, but the more I hung out with him, the more I realized I couldn't do without him. He's one of the really, really great, great actors of the Scandinavian countries and the world, to be honest. I'm super proud that he's accepted. He's tender and sweet, but he also knows how to not idealize characters. He can be a real asshole on screen, and he can play a narcissist. He knows who that is. He understands people in an intimate, intricate way, psychologically. He's sophisticated like that. I call him Mr. Cinema because he's worked with everyone internationally.

Everyone, every kind of film, big or small, every visual medium, from Lars von Trier to “Andor” and “Dune.”

And he loves movies like me. He watches movies. He eats movies for breakfast. He comes on set more than any other actor I've worked with. He doesn't want to be away in his trailer in the morning. I have my whole method of talking to the team, prepping them emotionally for what we're going through, how they can help me, help the actors, they're co-directors. I say, “we're changing wheels on the Formula One car.” When the actors are out, we're moving fast. And Stellan comes and he sits next to me: “Yeah, what do you want to do?” He will understand movements. “Okay, so I should get up a little later than this.” “Great idea. Yeah, please. That's smart Stellan. Mr. Cinema.” He has all that craft. But in this one, he wanted to go out on a limb, and he wanted to lose control, which is the kind of movie I do. I try to create an unhinged chaotic state just in the moment of shooting. We plan a lot. We have rehearsals. We trust each other, but to give them a risk, a chance for something special. And he wanted that.

 










What did you see that Renate could do here, that you hadn't let her do before?

She is an actor that brings unexpectedness, mystery and hard, precise work. So that combo is exciting. After “The Worst Person,” I felt we had known each other, but the way she opened up in that role, I saw potential. She was quite naive in playing a young character in “The Worst Person,” whereas Nora carries a burden of a trajectory that's fixed. She's as ambitious as Nora, she's quite opposite of Julie in the previous film. I saw that aspect of Renate. I knew she would understand. And we share that. We've both been that person, in a way, in a different version in our lives, but someone who's so driven and it gives you a sense of life and connectedness, and it also could be a coping mechanism of avoidance as well as communication in itself. It's both.

One dramatic and comedic set piece is at the beginning, when Nora freaks out with intense stage fright before opening night of August Strindberg's play “Miss Julie,” in which she is the lead. She's busting out of her corset, unable to breathe. Where did that come from?

I know two actors in Norway, great stage actors, who have stage fright like crazy. One of them, it becomes more physical, and he vomits a lot during the whole stage performance of “Hamlet.” We all have our performance anxieties, right? That's a part of creating. And then I know a woman who kept trying to run away. And I wanted to have levity as well, not to be too self-serious about the artists. But it's a human thing that we have approach and avoidance at the same time with things that we care for that we're also scared of, because they dominate us. Renate does not suffer from stage fright. She's actually bold and gutsy, but she knows that there's a perversion going on stage in an almost evolutionary, animalistic way. To be in front of everyone's gaze is the most dangerous place for any being in the animal kingdom. You're extremely vulnerable, and you're in a masochistic sense exposing yourself. 

 










I have deep respect and love for actors on the film set. They keep their heart open and their emotions open for 8-10, hours, emotions that the rest of us would put away after 10 minutes. We would finish crying and say, “Ah, I don't want to feel that anymore.” They keep it open. So I thought, behind all the beauty or facade of a success, there's also that vulnerability of the gaffer tape dress that is broken and it's all just made up by a great bunch of people. It's my love letter to the gang that makes something. It's messy and beautiful at its best, and we're all just trying to talk about something because we don't know how not to, but also to try to generously share it with people, not to say, “Oh, you have to be an artist, understand my movie.” Rather the opposite, saying, “Hey, these are messy people and in the story, I'm trying to create the idea that the communication of art is a key to open a family story to a deeper level.” That's what I'm trying.

Finally, that does happen. It's reconciliation? 

It works, right? Reconciliation. That's the word, and not the cheap kind where you say, “Well, you'll have that dialogue, and they will share their feelings, and everything is okay.” I don't believe that's life. I believe that maybe there is a distance. Reconciliation isn't that we have to agree or have to get acceptance for everything, but that we will negotiate enough our differences that we can listen to the other and say, “We might not ever agree, but I can find peace with you.” And that's what I'm longing for, on many levels. 

 










So you've experienced psychotherapy?

I've had that experience. Yes, I've been fortunate enough to to learn that there are certain things maybe that you have to also deal with, yourself, to accept that not all relationships can be resolved objectively. 

Do you believe that if you don't learn the language of psychotherapy you will never understand yourself? 

The aim of certain psychodynamic therapy is to go beyond the language, to reach an emotional presence in yourself. There is some aspect of human life which is language without words. I believe that in trauma and woundedness, there is unspokenness we transfer to our children, tons of things without language that we don't control. This is how humans grow and develop and connect or disconnect. We know this to be true in our emotional experience, all of us. And isn't that non-spoken space connected to the possibility of art, the possibility of how music moves us, or how we mirror ourselves in a movie, and all our friends don't like it, but we feel deeply moved, and we don't know how to defend it, but we know it's true to us? Yes, that space exists in art.

What are “jazz takes”? 

Anders Danielsen Lie, my dear collaborator, he's a musician as well. He said, “what you're asking for towards the end of doing a scene, let's call it a ‘jazz take.'” It's perfect, because you know the structure, you know the tune. But let's phrase it differently. Let's play it your way, different. The loose take encourages the actors to continually search and fall on their ass. It's the “hang loose” concept. Let's see where it goes. They know that I'm next to the camera, and they want to do something unexpected. They find it. And I sit there and I cry and I laugh and I love them. That's my job, to encourage the risk of making it look stupid, but then at the end it comes back.

 










One of the film's great set pieces is a moving breakthrough between the two sisters, played by Reinsve and Inga Ibsdotter Lilleaas. It was not scripted? 

It happens in the moment completely. It's written in one way, and everyone was in love with the written version. But on the day, we try to create an event, something that we didn't quite plan. Inga, the young sister, she didn't share with me her trajectory. It turned out that the film for her was about love and the power of it. She shows the way that she wants to get close to her depressed sister. And it was more moving in the story. It was like she was in control, and she opened up the sister's emotional register. She's actually bringing her own grief, this connectedness into the scene. 

Is Eskil Vogt on set? 

No. Never. During filming we don't talk so much. We do our talking before; we write together every day, and then he writes out the script. He's a better writer than me, so out of the year, maybe six weeks is spent apart at the end, when he writes and I edit and we meet and he writes again, and we do the actual writing. But we planned everything, we talked everything, we acted everything, and then I do rehearsals. So rehearsals is just about trying the elasticity with the actors. He's not there, and I show him the tapes. So he has that remote position. And then we rewrite. Then I go on set, and he leaves me alone until the second half of the edit, when I have something I want to show. 

 










Does he come into the editing room?

I do screenings with him and others and discuss. An important person I've worked with since day one is Olivier Bugge Coutté, the editor. Editors don't get enough respect. It's this triangle before and after. It's Eskil and Olivier and me. Eskil comes in and reminds us of things, and sees things, and that's important. But Olivier runs the room. He sees what we have. There's a dialectic between these two very smart collaborators. And then in the middle, we have beautiful Kasper Tuxen, the cinematographer, and the actors, who bring their own things. It's a complete collaboration. 

It seems that this movie is reaching people, they're understanding what you're talking about. They get it.

I'm happy we're doing great box office in France and Norway now, the two countries that have opened are tremendous. In France, after three weeks, we sold over 400,000 tickets and it's still going. And in Norway, the same thing, we're doubling the numbers from the previous one at least, if not more. So how the hell did that happen when cinematic box office is diminished generally? 

Who did you use for the narration? 

That is Benter Børsum, who's now 93 years old, and who played the lead in my grandfather's film “The Hunt” that was in Cannes in 1960. “Do you want to come and do a voiceover so that I link this experience of this film I've worked on with someone that my grandfather also worked with?” And she said, “Of course, I'd love to.”

 










Neon will open “Sentimental Value” in theaters on Friday, November 7.

Title: Watch Geese Perform “Taxes” on Kimmel
Description:
Geese were the musical guests on last night's episode of the recently restored Jimmy Kimmel Live!, performing “Taxes” from new album Getting Killed. Watch Cameron Winter and the band's rendition below.

Geese released their 3D Country follow-up last week, their first LP since Winter's solo debut Heavy Metal, released in January. The band will make its Coachella debut at the 2026 festival, after a huge and mostly sold-out North American tour that begins next week. Dates in Glasgow and London were recently added to the similarly oversubscribed UK leg of the tour.

Jimmy Kimmel, meanwhile, is firmly back in the saddle after public outrage (and a Disney subscriber exodus) over his postponement by Disney-owned ABC under pressure from the Trump administration. Alex G stopped by the studio earlier this week.

Title: Rochelle Jordan: Through the Wall Album Review
Description:
8.3

 Best New Music 

Genre:

Pop/R&B

Label:

EMPIRE

Reviewed:

October 2, 2025

On Through the Wall, Rochelle Jordan is a diva of the after‑hours, with control like Janet and poise like Diana Ross. Big hair, noir lighting, diamonds catching low light—she's grounded, unhurried. “Don't be afraid to take up space,” she earnestly declares at the start of “On 2 Something.” Across 17 sensorial tracks, the mood is intimate and dusky, luxurious and hypnotic; you can feel the velvet rope unhooking from the stanchion. It's the right setting for an album that treats dance music as a space for composure and desire, and pop as the chariot that gets you there.

The British Canadian artist's third album doesn't reinvent her wheel so much as buff the rims to a mirrored sheen: It's a late-night, pop-forward dance record engineered for people who like to move as good as they think. Through the Wall doubles down on a sound Jordan already dominates—house music with pop polish and R&B steering—while making the case that polish can also be a kind of risk. It's less about futurist shock than present clarity: controlled tempos, velvet hooks, and a vocal style that prefers precision to pyrotechnics. If her peers (Kelela, Dawn Richard, FKA twigs, George Riley, Nia Archives) still bend the form until it squeals, Jordan's flex is subtler—she keeps the party at a low boil and wins on consistency.

In 2021, Jordan made a return to the scene on Play With the Changes, a jam-packed attempt to prove herself in a crowded house. Through the Wall opens the windows. The tempos glide; the drums are sculpted; her voice—low, cool, assured—reserves her honeyed falsetto for the sweetest escapes. Jordan's third album makes a confident argument for mid-tempo dance music that's deep rather than eruptive. These songs don't chase the weird for its own sake; they favor a steady after‑midnight sway that invites you closer, then closer still, until you're inhaling the same smoke. There's no doubt that Through the Wall feels akin to '90s R&B dance pioneers like Janet Jackson, but for fans of contemporary groovesters, you may place this record in the same camp as those from Jessie Ware, Amber Mark, or even Victoria Monét.

Jordan is a master of restraint and subtle expression. She doesn't belt; she breathes, trusting her phrasing to carry the heat. On the sugary highlight “Sweet Sensation,” she slips out of Brandy-esque melisma to assert that smolder can stand alone. On “Crave,” a love song produced by Chicago house legend Terry Hunter, Jordan struts exquisitely; club music was always about feeling as much as stimulation, and Jordan is tapped into the heart of its lineage. Songs like “Crave,” “TTW,” and “Sum” keep steady four-to-the-floor rhythms that invite slink, not sprint.

The record's polish comes from curation as much as performance. Jordan doesn't just hire producers; she maps a dance diaspora of contemporary pop, Chicago and Detroit house, and UK garage, and threads herself through it. Standout favorite “Bite the Bait” gets a chrome‑sleek electro sheen from Jimmy Edgar that lets her cool vocal glide like lip gloss; “Around” draws on producer Hamdi's UK bass sensibility, and Jordan rides the low end, sounding featherweight and self-assured. “I'm Your Muse” sharpens her chanteuse era into a point. Over KLSH and Machinedrum's lithe kick, she purrs instructions, blurring ad‑lib and hook until the whole thing feels like an invitation and a boundary at once: “Just say you love me/Say you use me/Say you're feening.” Elsewhere, KLSH keeps the pulse clean (“Ladida,” “Never Enough”), and the snap of Machinedrum and WaveIQ's beat for “On 2 Something” gives her space to flirt in the margins. Jordan's scene knowledge reads lived-in, not borrowed, and her voice remains the constant center of gravity.

If you come craving rupture or the feral edge of club experimentalism, you might want to look elsewhere. There are moments—especially for fans of her more edgy cuts—where you expect the veneer to crack. But the choice here is deliberate: restraint as seduction, control as heat source. Through the Wall makes its case without grandstanding, proof that command can be quiet. Jordan has always balanced sultry R&B with a steady impulse steeped in UK dance; the difference now is how serene she sounds in these choppy waters. Through the Wall isn't the loudest record in the room, but it's among the most replayable at 2 a.m.—and by that time, it's only true party people in the house.

Title: Olivia Dean: The Art of Loving Album Review
Description:
6.9

Genre:

Pop/R&B

Label:

Capitol UK / Polydor

Reviewed:

October 2, 2025

“I've done all the classic stuff,” Olivia Dean sings on “Nice to Each Other,” the lead single from her second album, The Art of Loving. And it certainly does seem that way—the rising British neo-soul star studied songwriting at London's prestigious BRIT School, got her first gig as a backing vocalist for the chart-topping dance-pop group Rudimental, and, throughout the 2020s, has worked her way up the United Kingdom's traditional ladder to stardom: BBC Introducing Artist of the Year, Glastonbury, Jools Holland. She cites Amy Winehouse and Carole King in interviews and has covered the Supremes and Nat King Cole. So I'll respectfully disagree with Dean's follow-up claim, that “all the classic stuff… it never works.” Arriving at the peak of her fame to date, The Art of Loving is a genuinely lovely collection of would-be classic pop songs, all variations on the titular theme. It moves with the timeless grace of some bygone, indeterminate era in music and celebrity, one that maybe never existed to begin with.

Prior to recording The Art of Loving, Dean had immersed herself—as many of her generation have and many more surely will—in bell hooks' All About Love. “‘Gotta throw some paint,' that's what bell would say,” she sings on the album's brief prelude. More precisely, Dean drew inspiration from an exhibition of the same name by the artist Mickalene Thomas, itself a response to hooks' influential work of theory. Whereas Thomas' paintings are elaborate and rhinestone-encrusted, The Art of Loving is filled with little marvels of economy. Dean and executive producer Zach Nahome borrow a spare set of bongos from a Laurel Canyon open mic, a buttery Brill Building Rhodes organ, and some well-placed bah-bah-bahs courtesy of Motown girl-groups. In their fastidious arrangements, little details that might otherwise go unnoticed—a five-note, hyaline piano motif on “Nice to Each Other” or the passage of double-time horns that follow the first chorus of “Let Alone the One You Love”—instead become focal points.

That these songs don't end up sounding vacuum-sealed is credit to Dean's unfussy warmth. Given 12 hours, a tree might unfurl its leaves towards the glow of her voice, which, compared to her contemporaries, is neither as brashly operatic as RAYE's nor as steely as Jorja Smith's. “I'm the perfect mix of Saturday night and the rest of your life,” Dean proclaims on “So Easy (To Fall in Love)”: “Anyone with a heart would agree.” If anything, she strikes that balance a little too well; parts of The Art of Loving play like background music for the grander emotional beats elsewhere on the album. “So Easy” could stand in for the bossa nova record Dean mentions on “Man I Need,” whose 12/8 rhythm keeps time with the spring in your step after a great first date. Of course, the right accompaniment can transform a daily routine into something sublime, and The Art of Loving is, in all sincerity, a perfect album to cook or clean to.

Dean presents as thoughtful about the limits of her tableau vivant approach to music. The videos for “Nice to Each Other” and “Man I Need” both take place on what are very obviously soundstages, a nod to the silver-screen artifice inherent to the tradition she's working in. Dean's writing can be bracingly incisive: In two lines (“I don't know where the switches are/Or where you keep the cutlery”) she captures the unease of an old flame rendered newly unfamiliar. Too often, though, it's weighed down with clichés and mixed metaphors, and both “Close Up” and “Baby Steps” cross the line from charmingly retro into pastiche. The Art of Loving reminds me of Leslie Feist's exemplary pivot to coffeeshop pop and lounge jazz on her albums Let It Die and The Reminder, but Feist also had her wild youth as a Broken Social Scenester behind her by then. Dean's meticulous replicas are nearly impeccable; it's high time she starts throwing some paint around.

Title: crushed: no scope Album Review
Description:
6.7

Genre:

Rock

Label:

Ghostly International

Reviewed:

October 2, 2025

In video game lingo, to take someone out “no scope” is to rush directly at them with weapons blasting, not bothering to aim but shooting directly from the hip. It's less cold-blooded than picking someone off from a distance, executed in a rush of pure adrenaline and energy. You're running and shooting, undefended and reckless, willing to risk it all for the sake of an ambush or else just out of impatience or boredom. This is the energy the alt-pop duo crushed say they're bringing to their debut, a collection of songs about heartbreak rooted in the hazy, quantized world of mid-'90s Garbage and Massive Attack. What they deliver is something closer to a high-level combo attack—a rigorously disciplined, tidily executed exercise in pushing the right buttons at the right time, whether emotional or otherwise. It's a precise and inventive record that shows off Shaun Durkan and Bre Morell's technical skills, but its rigorous perfection means no matter how advanced its rendering may be, the end result sometimes feels flat.

no scope follows 2023's extra life EP, and yes, it's a theme. Video game concepts show up across both records (extra life's “respawn” refers to a slain character coming back to life; no scope's “oneshot” is inspired by an obnoxious boss fight in Elden Ring). It's fitting, considering Durkan and Morell live in different states (Oregon and California, respectively) and treat crushed as a kind of immersive online co-op project. But it's also a nice mirror of their philosophical approach. As with extra life, no scope ruminates on what might have been, navigating the seemingly endless terrain of heartbreak like it's wandering through an open-world game with no real task in mind.

To build their sandbox, Durkan and Morell drew heavily from a shared playlist of '90s radio faves like the Sundays, Dido, and Cowboy Junkies. You might hear a touch of those artists, as well as the aforementioned Massive Attack, scattered around no scope's remarkably dense but well-organized soundstage. But where the long shadow of VH1-style adult alternative looms largest is in the record's overall tone: This is music that seems to take place right after the ugliness and unpredictability of catharsis has passed. Morell's vocals are higher in the mix than they were on extra life, putting more emphasis on her straightforwardly beautiful melodies and giving these songs a greater sense of clarity.

When it works, as in opener “exo,” which cracks into sunlight right as Morell's narrator strides confidently into the chorus, it can be affecting. The songs bleed into one another with the tear-soaked associational logic of a breakup. Guitars slide off of breakbeats, pitch-shifted vocal samples and weird funk jams web the space between tracks in reveries of dissociation. There are handclaps so tiny they sound like fingersnaps in “starburn,” and a guitar whose delay effect puts it off-beat with the rest of the song. It feels like there are never fewer than eight things happening, and even when those eight things seem to be taking different paths, they always end up in the same place. It's ready-made pop music à la Durkan and Morel's fave Natalie Imbruglia, but the level of a synthesis here is a reminder that what can look like broad strokes are often the results of hundreds of fibers all moving at once.

Shoot for the moon, the saying goes, and that seems to have been the guiding principle for a lot of no scope. It's admirable to hear a bedroom-pop project not just take influence from past hits, but to actually try to recreate their sense of scale; pop ambition is its own form of experimentalism in this context. But at times on no scope, crushed overshoot their mark and wind up in a place that might look majestic but feels remote. Nowhere is this more clear than in “heartcontainer,” whose conventionally beautiful melody and processional tempo come off like contemporary praise and worship music, something not helped by the opening couplet being, “I'm on my knees/I'm crying for you.” Morell sings it with admirable poise and grace, but that's part of the problem; the emotional devastation toward which the lyrics point is incompatible with the song's flawlessness, a problem that recurs throughout the album.

This is a question of emphasis and not approach: There is plenty happening on no scope that proves the emotional durability of crushed's sound. At a time when seemingly a third of all bands are mining the '90s for parts, Durkan and Morell have arranged their recovered scraps in what feels like a genuinely novel way. Rather than call it a day after assembling their pastiche, crushed paint a line between the sexy glum of trip-hop and the plainspoken confessionals of artists like Madi Diaz and Phoebe Bridgers. In the end, this future-facing, tech-savvy, hyperslick music most resembles a vintage, analog form: no scope is a singer-songwriter record.
